author: Linda Collison
content: Right on Sarah Johnson — and right on Dr. Gladys West.

author: Phil
content: Sarah, I was thinking the same thing wheb I posted that.

author: Sarah Johnson
content: Phil — men ALWAYS got the credit back in those days. Organizations need to play catch-up rewriting history while some of these smart women are still alive. I’d like a cup of coffee at my desk now, please.

author: Dave S
content: This fine woman is now 86. When she started her career she did a lot work with paper and pencil and chalk boards, then with huge mainframes which did basic calculations and were probably less powerful than my iPad. Being inducted into The Air Force Space and Missle Hall of Fame for making a MAJOR CONTRIBUTION to the development of the Global Positioning System means she is and was one smart chick.

author: Phil
content:
First of new fleet of GPS satellites set for launch – CBS News
3-days ago:

After months of delays, the U.S. Air Force is about to launch the first of a new generation of GPS satellites, designed to be more accurate, secure and versatile. … The satellite is scheduled to lift off this week from Cape Canaveral, Florida, aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket.
https://www.cbsnews.com/news/first-of-new-fleet-of-gps-satellites-set-for-launch/

author: Phil
content:
Dig deeper:

She may have had a hand in it, but…

Roger L. Easton of the Naval Research Laboratory, Ivan A. Getting of The Aerospace Corporation, and Bradford Parkinson of the Applied Physics Laboratory are credited with inventing it..
https://www.quora.com/Who-invented-the-GPS-tracking-device
